protocol_name: Plumage pigments identification by High-performance liquid chromatography
protocol_name_html: Plumage pigments identification by High-performance liquid chromatography
description: As one of the most recognizable characteristics in birds, plumage colour has a high impact on understanding the evolution and mechanisms of colouration. Feather and skin are ideal tissues to explore the genomics and complexity of colour patterns in vertebrates. Two species of the genus Chrysolophus, golden pheasant (Chrysolophus pictus) and Lady Amherst’s pheasant (Chrysolophus amherstiae), exhibit brilliant colours in their plumage, but with extreme phenotypic differences, making these two species great models to investigate plumage colouration mechanisms in birds. Here we provide details of the protocols used for plumage pigments identification by High-performance liquid chromatography. The fat-soluble pigments (carotenoids) and oxidation products of melanins (TTCA and PTCA) can be qualitatively and quantificationally analyzed by HPLC with the corresponding standards, respectively.
warning: The sample pretreatment process should be completed in the draught cupboard.

guidelines: Carotenoids should be extracted from feathers by a thermochemical treatment. The melanins from feathers should be treated under alkaline H2O2 conditions to obtain oxidation products.
status_info: We use this protocol in our group and it is working

components.data: Each type of coloured feather was soaked in ethanol and hexanes in turn so that surface lipids were removed.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Each type of coloured feather was soaked in ethanol and hexanes in turn so that surface lipids were removed.

components.data: Pigmented barbs were trimmed into pieces, weighed and placed into a 10ml glass tube which can be capped tightly, and then 1ml acidified pyridine was infused to cover the pieces.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Pigmented barbs were trimmed into pieces, weighed and placed into a 10ml glass tube which can be capped tightly, and then 1ml acidified pyridine was infused to cover the pieces.

components.data: The tube was filled with argon gas and placed in a 368K water bath for 3 h.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: The tube was filled with argon gas and placed in a 368K water bath for 3 h.

components.data: After cooling to room temperature, 2 ml pure water and 1ml hexane: tert-butyl methyl ether (1:1) was added into the tube in order to separate the carotenoid pigments from the solution.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: After cooling to room temperature, 2 ml pure water and 1ml hexane: tert-butyl methyl ether (1:1) was added into the tube in order to separate the carotenoid pigments from the solution.

components.data: The mixture was vigorously shaken for 2 min and centrifuged at 3000 rpm for 5 min.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: The mixture was vigorously shaken for 2 min and centrifuged at 3000 rpm for 5 min.

components.data: The supernatant was transferred to a clean tube, dried under nitrogen gas, and stored at 193 K for subsequent analysis.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: The supernatant was transferred to a clean tube, dried under nitrogen gas, and stored at 193 K for subsequent analysis.

components.data: Dried pigment was dissolved in HPLC mobile phase (methanol/acetonitrile, 50:50 v/v, +0.05% triethylamine), filtered through a nylon syringe filter and injected into an SIL-20A HPLC system (Shimadzu, Japan) equipped with a YMC C-30 Carotenoid column (5 μm, 4.6 mm × 250 mm; YMC, Japan) and an SPD-20A UV/Vis detector (Shimadzu, Japan). An isocratic system at a flow rate of 1.5 ml/min for 40 min was programmed and data were collected at 450 nm.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Dried pigment was dissolved in HPLC mobile phase (methanol/acetonitrile, 50:50 v/v, +0.05% triethylamine), filtered through a nylon syringe filter and injected into an SIL-20A HPLC system (Shimadzu, Japan) equipped with a YMC C-30 Carotenoid column (5 μm, 4.6 mm × 250 mm; YMC, Japan) and an SPD-20A UV/Vis detector (Shimadzu, Japan). An isocratic system at a flow rate of 1.5 ml/min for 40 min was programmed and data were collected at 450 nm.

components.data: A total of 20 mg barbs were weighed and ground into powder in liquid nitrogen.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: A total of 20 mg barbs were weighed and ground into powder in liquid nitrogen.

components.data: After warming to room temperature, 2 ml pure water was infused to the powder and 200 μl suspensions were placed into a 10ml glass tube, to which 750 μl 1 mol/ l K2CO3 and 50 μl 30% H2O2 were added.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: After warming to room temperature, 2 ml pure water was infused to the powder and 200 μl suspensions were placed into a 10ml glass tube, to which 750 μl 1 mol/ l K2CO3 and 50 μl 30% H2O2 were added.

components.data: After the mixtures were shaken at 298K for 20 h, 100 μl 10% Na2SO3 and 280 μl 6 mol/l HCl were used to decompose the residual H2O2 and acidify the solution, respectively.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: After the mixtures were shaken at 298K for 20 h, 100 μl 10% Na2SO3 and 280 μl 6 mol/l HCl were used to decompose the residual H2O2 and acidify the solution, respectively.

components.data: The reaction products then were centrifuged at 4000 g for 1 min and an aliquot of each supernatant was injected into the same HPLC system except equipped with a Wondasil C18 column (5 μm, 4.6 mm × 250 mm; GL Sciences, Japan). TTCA and PTCA were analyzed with a mobile phase of 0.1 mol/l potassium phosphate buffer (pH 2.1) / methanol, 99:1 (v/v) at 318K at a flow rate of 0.7 ml/ min, and data were collected at 269 nm.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: The reaction products then were centrifuged at 4000 g for 1 min and an aliquot of each supernatant was injected into the same HPLC system except equipped with a Wondasil C18 column (5 μm, 4.6 mm × 250 mm; GL Sciences, Japan). TTCA and PTCA were analyzed with a mobile phase of 0.1 mol/l potassium phosphate buffer (pH 2.1) / methanol, 99:1 (v/v) at 318K at a flow rate of 0.7 ml/ min, and data were collected at 269 nm.
